allScrap.description: Not much but a chassis left, but what else do you need? Just the frame is worth ten times the weight of it. And when it was whole? Well, you'd probably never even know it had blown past if it weren't for the small sandstorm it kicked up.
You never know what might end up out here. That thing belongs in a museum, but it's worth its weight in scrap all the same.
The Bamak make awful big ships for being as small as they are, huh?
You'd think something so massive would have even one recognizable trait or insignia, but neither of you have any idea what this thing is. All you know is it's big, and you want it.
Something this massive shouldn't be possible. Even in the never ending wastes that surround it, this rusting hulk of a freighter ship looms large. A mighty haul if you can get it moving.

If you've ever met someone form Galatan V you'll hear horror stories about these things. The entire planetary government ran on them for about 200 standard years and their techs stopped being able to interface with them for the latter 100.
You've never seen an intergalactic carrier so bedecked with analogue audio systems before. Bet it made a whole lot of noise in its day.
Not much better than a couple of tin cans and a cord of ebruliam hair.
You could fit one of these in the palm of your hand, but then there wouldn't be much of a hand left after, would there?
Never designed to be terrestrial, it's almost sad to see it so far from where it's meant to be.
The WD-40k is beloved by any scrap buyer who knows a deal when they see one. Nothing crushes quite like it.
The Paranti don't get around much but they hear more than you or I could know exists. If this thing were operational, you'd never have known it existed.
Always gets on my nerves that the military types seem to contract the best designers. EIT configurations might inspire fear around the system, but at least they look cool as all hell doing it.
Something meant for burrowing tunnels through loose sand near the surface probably should have taken the local wildlife into consideration, eh? You're never alone out there. Never.

Story goes that another scrapper once mistook these for some graphinium and snorted a small handful over a few minutes. She lived, but you could never tell who was calling the shots up there afterwords.
Destabilizing is just a fancy way of saying this thing used to be so loud it was banned from being used on any inhabited planet.

Now these were a disappointment. They were supposed to be the next big thing for the Maelstrom Cup a long while ago but never made it off the starting line in one piece. Been blacklisted in legal races ever since.
This stuff would be worth a fortune if it had ever worked.

The colors alone indicate that this thing belong to some important Dazaak council member. Not recommended to fly off planet though as you never know who might be holding a grudge against our celestial neighbors.

Wonder what kinda lives got lived in there. I hope their data got transferred though, I never mine it before smelting them down. Read enough diaries of bored travelers and unrequited lovers for this lifetime.
If there were anything more left of this speeder, one of you would certainly recognize it. As it stands you're just glad whatever crashed in it is long gone.
One has to wonder how something meant to be so immovable made its way down from the highways and wormholes. Then again the waste haulers have moved much that was never meant to be shifted.
Great for a personal jump-jet or refrigerated backpack. Once outfitted a customer with a two-in-one.
Discontinued only a few weeks after they hit the market because of a "feature" that sent the AI after their competitor's machines. A rare find, but be careful reactivating it around other drones.
It's interesting to see one of these up close. In outer orbit you'd never get within optical range if you came up against something like this.
Can't tell you how much I wish this thing was still in orbit. Hoping our little beacon up there can at least pull down the Strom Race next week.
One of the old style, but something about the shape makes me feel at home.
Hard to tell where half of these cooling units come from. At least this one looks to be in only a handful of pieces.
Would be nice to get this up and running again. Any good orbital barrier needs a few.
Nothing is quite as loud as these if you can hear anything over 500,000 hz.
The nozzle might appear benign and agrarian, but Reed Industries has likely stolen more water than just about any other known corporation to supply their hydrofarms
If you ever get off this rock you'll get tired of seeing these things real quick. But I guess they're neat to look at the first thousand times or so.
